bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, September 10, 1911

div1.p: Carter explains the difficulties of being a navy wife and criticizes his daughter's possible suitors.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, September 10, 1911
div1.opener:
On my return I found 3 letters requiring answer from the Is
Isthmus - Curry: Hearn & Dulsky & the 1st two apropos de sicion a
nuisance.
I send a clipping from the
Outlook - which is partly but only
partly true
Hasten la Vista
H.R.C.
UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH AND MARINE-HOSPITAL SERVICE,
OFFICE OF MEDICAL OFFICER IN COMMAND.
Louisville, Ky
Sept 10 19011.
My Dear Little Daughter,
div1.p:
You weren't much bigger in last Thurswhen you
wrote your letter than when you were out “in
the Dark Night” “with henny Papa” “and a Big
Dog”,- I think he ought to be all capitals,
and I wish I had stayed over Monday, you would
have had no bother at all, I am inclined to
think this trouble came from your nervous
condition (physical & pschycical) rather than the
reverse-this is despite of Freud.

Of course there have got to be Naval Officers
& therefore I presume women have got to
Marry them. Yet I sh'd say that it by no means
an ideal life the navy women lead. A
life that one would require very cogent
reasons to elect. I do not agree with you that the
man is useful only during war, because
his

readiness to fight efficiently is at all times
useful to prevent war. His work is
always useful & most useful where
by his efficiently he renders war
with the U.S inadvisable to another country.
But his wife's position seems to me
cruelly hard & only a perfect willingness
to life live single - like Marian Carter - or - a-gran
absorbing passion would render - it endurable
Do you remember your little piece “I will
not love you knew.” That seems to express
what I think on the subject - as I think it did you of Feeling.
Also of all the naval men I have seen Mr. Bur-
well was the only one as a man - not consider-
ing the disadvantage of his occupation -I tho ever
thought was your-equal-in your-class so to
speak. I had no special objection to Mr. F. nor in-
deed what was told of his shooting the stock on
the Reina Mercedes was, especially as he never
said a word of it, was a gallant action, a very
gallant action, & if you had really cared for
him I would not have opposed you. Yet I would
have
have been sorry & very doubtful if you would
have been happy. I don't think you would
have been. He First his occupation & 2d, while
he was a man, which nonefew of the others showed
themselves, yet he was not a man of refinement
nor of real elevation of feeling (& he was most uncommonly queer). Burwell was
both. My own opinion is that the distance of
time thows a certain glamour ofover him & any
girl naturally likes a man who shews openly
that he greatly admires her, especially if he
be a manly man. You did very wisely in not
letting - or - making - yourself care for him. If
you had & had accepted him I think it would
have been a great pity & the odds heavily a-
gainst your leading a happy life. Unless
you did, or lied most successfully, I would have
not been happy either
.

We purpose to leave on the 28th in the morning
& to lay over - at S. Francisco from 2.08 P.M. Oct 2 to
10:30 A.M. Oct 4

Do you know I think the agr

So I hope you will get here
about the 20 - or - 19. in the evening
Sunday is the best day to travel
as the Pullmans are not crowded
that day. If you could leave Satur-
day night you would have a pleaster
pleasanter trip than
any other day. Saturday however is the 17th. Monday
is the most crowded day in the week.
We will finish the packing except trunk, Tuesday. I think but
leave somethings for your judgement. I will
engage the sleeping berths tomorrow & write
to Truster, at Angel Island, to get my state-
rooms: - Have to send check. Also will take down
about 100 lbs of books to see if I can sell them
& leave about 250 to 300 lbs more behind
-unpacked. We take no crockery & very few winter
clothes - those by freight. Take a very few books
good night my dear. Commend me to Drs Hamman &
Watson & to the chief nurse, & should you see her Miss Rio-
pelle.
